00039 #define NaN numeric_limits<double>::quiet_NaN()

00049 double AffxStatistics::factorial(int i)
00050 {
00051         double lResult = 1;
00052         for (int iIndex = 2; (iIndex <= i); iIndex++)
00053         {
00054                 lResult *= iIndex;
00055         }
00056         return lResult;
00057 }
00058 
00059 double AffxStatistics::binocdf(int x, int n, double p)
00060 {
00061         double dSum = 0;
00062         for (int iIndex = 0; (iIndex <= x); iIndex++)
00063         {
00064                 double a = (factorial(n) / (factorial(iIndex) * (factorial(n - iIndex))));
00065                 dSum += (a * pow(p, iIndex) * pow((1 - p), (n - iIndex)));
00066         }
00067         return dSum;
00068 }
00069 
00070 int AffxStatistics::binoinv(double y, int n, double p)
00071 {
00072         int iResult = 0;
00073         for (int i = 0; (i < n); i++)
00074         {
00075                 if (binocdf(i, n, p) >= y)
00076                 {
00077                         iResult = i;
00078                         break;
00079                 }
00080         }
00081         return iResult;
00082 }

00084 // http://home.online.no/~pjacklam/notes/invnorm/
00085 // http://home.online.no/~pjacklam/notes/invnorm/impl/lea/lea.c
00086 /*
00087  * The standard normal CDF, for one random variable.
00088  *
00089  *   Author:  W. J. Cody
00090  *   URL:   http://www.netlib.org/specfun/erf
00091  *
00092  * This is the erfc() routine only, adapted by the
00093  * transform stdnormal_cdf(u)=(erfc(-u/sqrt(2))/2;
00094  */
00095 // Q: What about copyright? 
00096 // A: You can use the algorithm, including any of the computer implementations listed in the section Computer implementations, for whatever purpuse you want, but please show common courtesy and give credit where credit is due. 
00097 
00098 double AffxStatistics::normcdf(double u)
00099 {
00100  const double a[5] = {
00101   1.161110663653770e-002,3.951404679838207e-001,2.846603853776254e+001,
00102   1.887426188426510e+002,3.209377589138469e+003
00103  };
00104  const double b[5] = {
00105   1.767766952966369e-001,8.344316438579620e+000,1.725514762600375e+002,
00106   1.813893686502485e+003,8.044716608901563e+003
00107  };
00108  const double c[9] = {
00109   2.15311535474403846e-8,5.64188496988670089e-1,8.88314979438837594e00,
00110   6.61191906371416295e01,2.98635138197400131e02,8.81952221241769090e02,
00111   1.71204761263407058e03,2.05107837782607147e03,1.23033935479799725E03
00112  };
00113  const double d[9] = {
00114   1.00000000000000000e00,1.57449261107098347e01,1.17693950891312499e02,
00115   5.37181101862009858e02,1.62138957456669019e03,3.29079923573345963e03,
00116   4.36261909014324716e03,3.43936767414372164e03,1.23033935480374942e03
00117  };
00118  const double p[6] = {
00119   1.63153871373020978e-2,3.05326634961232344e-1,3.60344899949804439e-1,
00120   1.25781726111229246e-1,1.60837851487422766e-2,6.58749161529837803e-4
00121  };
00122  const double q[6] = {
00123   1.00000000000000000e00,2.56852019228982242e00,1.87295284992346047e00,
00124   5.27905102951428412e-1,6.05183413124413191e-2,2.33520497626869185e-3
00125  };
00126  register double y, z;
00127 
00128  if (u != u)
00129   return NaN;
00130  if ((u == numeric_limits<double>::infinity()) || (u == -numeric_limits<double>::infinity()))
00131   return (u < 0 ? 0.0 : 1.0);
00132  y = fabs(u);
00133     if (y <= 0.46875*sqrt(2.0)) {
00134   /* evaluate erf() for |u| <= sqrt(2)*0.46875 */
00135   z = y*y;
00136   y = u*((((a[0]*z+a[1])*z+a[2])*z+a[3])*z+a[4])
00137        /((((b[0]*z+b[1])*z+b[2])*z+b[3])*z+b[4]);
00138   return 0.5+y;
00139  }
00140  z = exp(-y*y/2)/2;
00141  if (y <= 4.0) {
00142   /* evaluate erfc() for sqrt(2)*0.46875 <= |u| <= sqrt(2)*4.0 */
00143   y = y/sqrt(2.0);
00144   y =
00145 ((((((((c[0]*y+c[1])*y+c[2])*y+c[3])*y+c[4])*y+c[5])*y+c[6])*y+c[7])*y+c[8])
00146 
00147 
00148 /((((((((d[0]*y+d[1])*y+d[2])*y+d[3])*y+d[4])*y+d[5])*y+d[6])*y+d[7])*y+d[8]);
00149 
00150   y = z*y;
00151     } else {
00152   /* evaluate erfc() for |u| > sqrt(2)*4.0 */
00153   z = z*sqrt(2.0)/y;
00154   y = 2/(y*y);
00155         y = y*(((((p[0]*y+p[1])*y+p[2])*y+p[3])*y+p[4])*y+p[5])
00156     /(((((q[0]*y+q[1])*y+q[2])*y+q[3])*y+q[4])*y+q[5]);
00157         y = z*(sqrt(PI)-y);
00158     }
00159  return (u < 0.0 ? y : 1-y);
00160 };
00161 
00162 // http://home.online.no/~pjacklam/notes/invnorm/
00163 // http://home.online.no/~pjacklam/notes/invnorm/impl/lea/lea.c
00164 /*
00165  * The inverse standard normal distribution.
00166  *
00167  *   Author:      Peter J. Acklam <pjacklam@online.no>
00168  *   URL:         http://home.online.no/~pjacklam
00169  *
00170  * This function is based on the MATLAB code from the address above,
00171  * translated to C, and adapted for our purposes.
00172  */
00173 // Q: What about copyright? 
00174 // A: You can use the algorithm, including any of the computer implementations listed in the section Computer implementations, for whatever purpuse you want, but please show common courtesy and give credit where credit is due. 
00175 
00176 double AffxStatistics::norminv(double p)
00177 {
00178  const double a[6] = {
00179   -3.969683028665376e+01,  2.209460984245205e+02,
00180   -2.759285104469687e+02,  1.383577518672690e+02,
00181   -3.066479806614716e+01,  2.506628277459239e+00
00182  };
00183  const double b[5] = {
00184   -5.447609879822406e+01,  1.615858368580409e+02,
00185   -1.556989798598866e+02,  6.680131188771972e+01,
00186   -1.328068155288572e+01
00187  };
00188  const double c[6] = {
00189   -7.784894002430293e-03, -3.223964580411365e-01,
00190   -2.400758277161838e+00, -2.549732539343734e+00,
00191    4.374664141464968e+00,  2.938163982698783e+00
00192  };
00193  const double d[4] = {
00194    7.784695709041462e-03,  3.224671290700398e-01,
00195    2.445134137142996e+00,  3.754408661907416e+00
00196  };
00197 
00198  register double q, t, u;
00199 
00200  if ((p != p) || p > 1.0 || p < 0.0)
00201   return NaN;
00202  if (p == 0.0)
00203   return NaN;
00204  if (p == 1.0)
00205   return  NaN;
00206  q = min(p,1-p);
00207  if (q > 0.02425) {
00208   /* Rational approximation for central region. */
00209   u = q-0.5;
00210   t = u*u;
00211   u = u*(((((a[0]*t+a[1])*t+a[2])*t+a[3])*t+a[4])*t+a[5])
00212     /(((((b[0]*t+b[1])*t+b[2])*t+b[3])*t+b[4])*t+1);
00213  } else {
00214   /* Rational approximation for tail region. */
00215   t = sqrt(-2*log(q));
00216   u = (((((c[0]*t+c[1])*t+c[2])*t+c[3])*t+c[4])*t+c[5])
00217    /((((d[0]*t+d[1])*t+d[2])*t+d[3])*t+1);
00218  }
00219  /* The relative error of the approximation has absolute value less
00220     than 1.15e-9.  One iteration of Halley's rational method (third
00221     order) gives full machine precision... */
00222  t = normcdf(u)-q;    /* error */
00223  t = t*sqrt(2*PI)*exp(u*u/2);   /* f(u)/df(u) */
00224  u = u-t/(1+u*t/2);     /* Halley's method */
00225 
00226  return (p > 0.5 ? -u : u);
00227 };
